quotes.topic_title: Why consistency puts podcasts in top percentiles
quotes.text: Yes, there are four million podcasts. However, there are only about 150,000 podcasts that have had 10 episodes and have published in the last 10 days.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Provides a concrete data point showing how much smaller the pool of active, consistent podcasts is than the headline number suggests.

quotes.topic_title: Why consistency puts podcasts in top percentiles
quotes.text: So the easiest way to be in that top 5% ish. I don't know what the math there is. About 3%, 4% is to just stick to it.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Reframes “top percentile” performance as primarily a consistency game rather than a talent or growth-hack problem.

quotes.topic_title: Why consistency puts podcasts in top percentiles
quotes.text: Like if you just do an episode a week for 10 weeks, you're now in the top 4% of all podcasts that anyone has created.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Gives a simple, actionable consistency benchmark that dramatically improves relative standing among all podcasts.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: my goal here is to help you get better at the craft of building and growing products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets a clear “craft” orientation that frames product growth as a skill to deliberately improve, not just outcomes to chase.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When I was looking for advice on how to build a podcast, Chris shared this awesome deck with a ton of great advice that he's built throughout his journey, and so I thought it'd be fun to spend an episode talking about all the things that you should know about launching and growing a podcast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical methodology: codify learnings into a “deck” and use it as a structured guide for launching and scaling a podcast.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I use Notion to coordinate this very podcast, including my content calendar, my sponsors, and prepping guests for launch of each episode.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives a concrete operational example of the core systems needed to run a podcast (calendar, sponsors, guest prep) and how to manage them.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I use Notion to coordinate this very podcast, including my content calendar, my sponsors, and prepping guests for launch of each episode.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of using a single workspace tool to run an end-to-end podcast operation (planning, monetization, and guest prep).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Notion is an all-in-one team collaboration tool that combines note-taking, document sharing, wikis, project management, and much more into one space that's simple, powerful and beautifully designed.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical “single source of truth” model: consolidate multiple workflows into one system to reduce tool sprawl and coordination overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable framing of compliance as a growth gate—treat security readiness as a revenue enabler, not just a cost center.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Enter Vanta, over 3000 fast growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Specific adoption and automation data point that quantifies how much compliance effort can be reduced with automation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta can get you ready for security audits in weeks instead of months, less than a third of the time that it usually takes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable benchmark for planning timelines: aim to compress audit readiness cycles dramatically with the right tooling/process.

quotes.topic_title: Episode framing: PM lessons and podcast growth
quotes.text: But what I want to spend most of our time on is talking about how to launch a podcast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Clear episode framing that prioritizes a single, practical outcome—useful as a model for structuring creator/educational content.

quotes.topic_title: Episode framing: PM lessons and podcast growth
quotes.text: I feel like just putting a podcast on YouTube isn't enough, I need to learn the skills of YouTube.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Highlights a cross-channel growth lesson: distribution isn’t copy-paste; each platform requires its own craft and playbook.

quotes.topic_title: Episode framing: PM lessons and podcast growth
quotes.text: I joined my first startup probably 10 years ago and was like, "I will do anything."
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A practical career tactic for early-stage environments: maximize surface area for ownership and learning by being broadly useful.

quotes.topic_title: Episode framing: PM lessons and podcast growth
quotes.text: But it turns out we didn't have anyone who also was doing products, so they were like, "What should we build that people will buy?"
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A concise product-management north star that anchors work in customer demand and monetizable value.

quotes.topic_title: Episode framing: PM lessons and podcast growth
quotes.text: And I went through the interview process and they were like, "You're a PM." And I was like, "Oh, great, what does a PM do?"
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Memorable story showing how PM roles can be discovered through doing the work, not just through formal titles or prior clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Chris’s career journey to full-time creator
quotes.text: I'm kind of like a happenstance product person. I basically really liked startups, but I didn't know what job I could have as a non-technical person.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Highlights a practical career entry point: you can break into product from curiosity and startup exposure even without a technical background.

quotes.topic_title: Chris’s career journey to full-time creator
quotes.text: And I joined my first startup probably 10 years ago and was like, "I will do anything."
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A concrete, actionable posture for early-stage environments: maximize learning and opportunity by being broadly useful.

quotes.topic_title: Chris’s career journey to full-time creator
quotes.text: But it turns out we didn't have anyone who also was doing products, so they were like, "What should we build that people will buy?"
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Frames product work around a market-first question—building what people will actually buy—rather than internal preferences.

quotes.topic_title: Chris’s career journey to full-time creator
quotes.text: And I have a podcast where we share all the hacks to do all of it.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Captures the creator “value proposition” succinctly: package research and optimization into shareable, repeatable tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Chris’s career journey to full-time creator
quotes.text: I think I've now learned with a lot of time that being a PM is awesome. Being a PM at Google when we were working on Google Plus was not awesome.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that role satisfaction depends heavily on the specific product/context, not just the job title.

quotes.topic_title: Wealthfront Self-Driving Money and Autopilot concept
quotes.text: And so it was thrown into, "Let's do a bunch of customer research, let's talk to a lot of people and let's try to come up with as audacious of an idea as we could for how you fulfill the promise of automating and optimizing someone's entire financial life to the point that they don't have to think about their finances on a daily basis and they know the right things are happening."
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A clear product-development methodology: start with deep customer research, then define an audacious promise and design toward eliminating daily user effort.

quotes.topic_title: Wealthfront Self-Driving Money and Autopilot concept
quotes.text: And we heard from our customers forever that they pay us to not talk to someone, our demographic doesn't want a bunch of humans in the mix.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A contrarian customer insight that challenges the assumption that more human support is always better—some segments value automation and less interaction.

quotes.topic_title: Wealthfront Self-Driving Money and Autopilot concept
quotes.text: Yeah, the vision I had was what are the core pieces of financial life that are stressful? It's like, "I got to move money, I got to contribute to these different accounts. I want to make sure I have enough to pay my bills."
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A practical framing for product discovery: identify the recurring stress points and build automation around those specific jobs-to-be-done.

quotes.topic_title: Wealthfront Self-Driving Money and Autopilot concept
quotes.text: And so what we ended up with was a product called Autopilot that would monitor your core banking account, whether it was a checking account at Wealthfront or not at Wealthfront or whether it was an account at Wealthfront.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A concrete example of reducing adoption friction by designing around the user’s “core account,” even if it’s outside your product ecosystem.

quotes.topic_title: Wealthfront Self-Driving Money and Autopilot concept
quotes.text: It was like, "Let's make sure you keep this much as a three-month emergency fund, max out your Roth IRA. Let's make sure you max out your 529 for your kids and let's put the rest in your kind of taxable just brokerage account."
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A specific, implementable prioritization rule-set for automated money allocation (buffer first, then tax-advantaged accounts, then taxable investing).

quotes.topic_title: Testing, launch learnings, and product-market-fit reality
quotes.text: And the lesson was really find something people are reaching over the table want, and make sure you have that validation.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A simple product-market-fit heuristic: validate intense, pull-based demand before investing heavily.

quotes.topic_title: Testing, launch learnings, and product-market-fit reality
quotes.text: And then I created this thing, which I'm sure is not that new, but I would start pretending that the product existed in the interviews.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A practical user-research method to test real intent and workflows by interviewing as if the product is already live.

quotes.topic_title: Testing, launch learnings, and product-market-fit reality
quotes.text: And I think the takeaway, I would say the impact on the company was not as high as we had wanted in that it didn't become this wild top of funnel.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A reminder that even beloved features may fail as acquisition drivers, separating product value from growth impact.

quotes.topic_title: Testing, launch learnings, and product-market-fit reality
quotes.text: And then you hand it to them and you're like, "Do you want to use this thing?" And they're like, "Well." It's very hard to test that.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Highlights the gap between stated desire in interviews and actual adoption behavior—especially for habit-changing products.

quotes.topic_title: Testing, launch learnings, and product-market-fit reality
quotes.text: Andy would say product market fit is exponential organic growth.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A crisp definition of PMF that sets a high bar and clarifies why “useful” isn’t the same as “PMF.”

quotes.topic_title: How to innovate inside a larger company
quotes.text: But you think that customer research is all you need to build a product at a company, but figuring out how to create excitement internally and get buy-in from other teams because they're the ones that are going to build it.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Highlights the often-missed reality that internal alignment and enthusiasm are as critical as external customer validation in large companies.

quotes.topic_title: How to innovate inside a larger company
quotes.text: The end is creating this compelling vision for what you're building.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Reframes “done” from having positive research results to having a narrative that mobilizes the organization.

quotes.topic_title: How to innovate inside a larger company
quotes.text: So if you want to make a big bet, if you want to make a big impactful product, you have to bring people along with you.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A simple operating principle for big-bet innovation: adoption inside the company must be actively led, not assumed.

quotes.topic_title: How to innovate inside a larger company
quotes.text: And your ability to speak publicly, persuade people, build influence within the company. Those things are all as important as your ability to identify a user need and build a product that solves it.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Defines a dual-skill model for PMs in large orgs: product craft plus internal influence as equal pillars.

quotes.topic_title: How to innovate inside a larger company
quotes.text: Sometimes at a company it's really easy to get caught up in the research you've already done and the customers you've already talked to and you forget to kind of step outside and go talk to other people and see what other people are doing.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Actionable reminder to continuously refresh market understanding beyond formal research and existing customer panels.

quotes.topic_title: Vision vs features, and stating intent to build trust
quotes.text: There's these two components of it which are, what does it do, but what's the feeling you want someone to have?
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A simple framework for product/strategy communication: pair functional outcomes with the user’s emotional outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Vision vs features, and stating intent to build trust
quotes.text: But the people that I've had work for me or I've worked alongside that seem to always be the outperformers, are always the people that are just solely focused on having the most impact on the company.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Contrasts promotion-chasing with impact focus as the real driver of outsized performance.

quotes.topic_title: Vision vs features, and stating intent to build trust
quotes.text: I think the thing I learned, which I thanks to Andy Rachleff for teaching me this is when you push so hard for your ideas and you have really strong beliefs, you have to also make sure you state your intent.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Actionable leadership tactic: explicitly clarify intent to reduce perceived self-interest when advocating strongly.

quotes.topic_title: Vision vs features, and stating intent to build trust
quotes.text: And so he taught me, he's like, "It would go a long way before you said that, you said, "Hey guys, I've got some crazy ideas, but before I say them, I just want you to know that all I care about is that the company is successful. And I think this idea will make the company successful. And that's why I'm so excited about it. I don't need to own it. I don't care who owns it, I'm just really excited about it.""
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A verbatim script practitioners can use to preface bold proposals and build trust by signaling non-ego intent.

quotes.topic_title: Vision vs features, and stating intent to build trust
quotes.text: And I've learned that when you have crazy ideas and when you're pushing back against a lot of people, if you can make sure you constantly remind them why you're doing it and what you care about, it goes a lot further than if you just kind of come in there with sharp elbows and try to push for crazy things.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Practical guidance for influence: repeat the “why” and values behind pushback to increase receptivity.

quotes.topic_title: Big bets, slugging average, and ‘bet the company’ swings
quotes.text: I want to work on a project that if successful makes everything we do as a company today feel like it's not that important because we did something that was 10 times bigger than everything we're doing today. And what we're doing now is just 10% of the company.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A clear bar for identifying truly high-upside “big bet” projects: success should radically reframe the company’s current scope.

quotes.topic_title: Big bets, slugging average, and ‘bet the company’ swings
quotes.text: Andy, he always talks about slugging average, not batting average.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A memorable performance metric for innovation work: optimize for outsized wins rather than consistent small hits.

quotes.topic_title: Big bets, slugging average, and ‘bet the company’ swings
quotes.text: He's like, "I don't care if you hit the ball every time. If one in 10 times you hit a home run that's better than someone who hits it every three out of 10 times but gets out a lot."
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that prioritizes rare, massive outcomes over higher “success rates” with lower impact.

quotes.topic_title: Big bets, slugging average, and ‘bet the company’ swings
quotes.text: He's written a lot internally about the balance between working on iterative improvements to current features and then taking big bets and trying to find the balance amongst it all.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A practical operating model for leadership: explicitly balance incremental execution with exploration for step-change growth.

quotes.topic_title: Big bets, slugging average, and ‘bet the company’ swings
quotes.text: You got to balance it because you're often wrong.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A blunt reminder to design portfolios and processes that assume big bets will frequently fail.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast benefits and access to high-quality guests
quotes.text: The podcast gives you this great platform, you're like, "Well, I have a podcast. And so I would love to invite you on and help you amplify your message and spend an hour trying to understand everything about topic X, Y, Z."
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Shows how a podcast can be used as a mutually beneficial “reason” to reach out and secure time with high-quality guests.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast benefits and access to high-quality guests
quotes.text: But like what I'm I going to od? Randomly email this person I don't know and say, "Hey, I loved your book. Can I just ask you questions for 45 minutes?" I would never do that.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Highlights the social friction of cold outreach and why podcasting can remove awkwardness practitioners often underestimate.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast benefits and access to high-quality guests
quotes.text: But I randomly emailed him and said, "Hey, we've never met. But I have a podcast." I don't even think it had launched, "It's launching next week, but I'm really excited about it. Could I pick your brain?" And he was like, "Sure."
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A concrete example of landing a notable guest via a simple pitch—even before the show launched.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast benefits and access to high-quality guests
quotes.text: So I would say the biggest thing is it just gives you a platform to explore your curiosities on things provided that you can really focus the thing that you talk about on one vertical, niche, something so that people learn what it's about.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: curiosity-driven content works best when paired with a clear niche so listeners know what to expect.

quotes.topic_title: Podcast benefits and access to high-quality guests
quotes.text: Because the hardest part about podcast growth is there's like four million podcasts and you've got to find a way to stand out in a sea of many podcasts.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A memorable data point and growth constraint that reinforces why differentiation and positioning matter.

quotes.topic_title: Should you start a podcast? Commitment and workload
quotes.text: So absolutely, do not start the podcast if you wouldn't do it for free, making no amount of money in perpetuity or as long as you want to experiment with.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A commitment filter that prevents starting a podcast for the wrong reasons (money/status) when success is statistically unlikely.

quotes.topic_title: Should you start a podcast? Commitment and workload
quotes.text: If you just do an episode a week, for 10 weeks, you're now in the top 4% of all podcasts that anyone has created.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A counterintuitive data point showing consistency alone can differentiate you in a crowded market.

quotes.topic_title: Should you start a podcast? Commitment and workload
quotes.text: If you don't know if you love the thing, it's very easy, which is what I did to say, "I'm going to have one season of eight episodes."
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A low-risk “season” methodology for testing fit and building momentum without an indefinite commitment.

quotes.topic_title: Should you start a podcast? Commitment and workload
quotes.text: It's a lot more work than it seems. Everyone I know that has no podcast and goes to having a podcast, they're like, "Oh my gosh, I thought this was just once, one hour a week, I just talked to somebody."
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A reality check that highlights the hidden workload (prep, notes, editing, recruiting) practitioners should plan for.

quotes.topic_title: Should you start a podcast? Commitment and workload
quotes.text: So I'd say only do it if you're excited to do it, even if five people are on the other end.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A practical motivation test for whether you’ll sustain the effort through the low-audience early phase.

quotes.topic_title: Launch strategy, rankings momentum, and guest leverage
quotes.text: When it comes to launch, I would say one of my suggestions is to get a few things in the bag. Line up... You don't want to launch and then be scrambling. So I tend to think launching with two or three episodes, either all at once or in a week is a really valuable strategy.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Actionable launch tactic: bank episodes and release multiple quickly to avoid post-launch scramble and build early momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Launch strategy, rankings momentum, and guest leverage
quotes.text: And the reason for that is that the ranking charts are all driven by different variables than you would imagine. They're driven a lot by momentum of new subscribers, at least on the Apple charts than actual downloads.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Counterintuitive insight into Apple chart dynamics: subscriber velocity can matter more than raw downloads.

quotes.topic_title: Launch strategy, rankings momentum, and guest leverage
quotes.text: So you had the newsletter before. I had a newsletter I'd written on casually for various things throughout my life and for my last startup. And so I kind of put it all together to try to carry a big launch so that we really spike the rankings, maybe qualify for Apple does this new and noteworthy thing. And so there's a lot of stuff you can do to build momentum at launch, but at the end of the day, all the momentum in the world doesn't matter if your content's not good.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Balanced methodology: use existing audience to spike launch momentum, but treat content quality as the ultimate constraint.

quotes.topic_title: Launch strategy, rankings momentum, and guest leverage
quotes.text: So I always say, be you, be authentic. Try to be someone's favorite. Don't try to be everyone's okay podcast.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Memorable positioning advice: optimize for deep affinity with a subset rather than broad, mediocre appeal.

quotes.topic_title: Launch strategy, rankings momentum, and guest leverage
quotes.text: Because every time I have a guest where I'm like, "I really think this person's going to move the metrics." It doesn't. And then I interview someone who no one has ever heard of, and I get these emails like, "Wow, that was such a good episode. Can't be. Oh man, I'm so glad you did that one."
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Contrarian programming lesson: “big-name” guests don’t reliably drive performance, while unknown guests can create standout episodes.

quotes.topic_title: Be someone’s favorite: true fans and consistency rituals
quotes.text: There's this whole idea of your build your 1000 true fans. And I think anytime you're creating something in the world, you want people to be your advocates for it because those are the people that are going to share it.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Introduces the “1,000 true fans” framework and ties it to building an advocacy engine for growth.

quotes.topic_title: Be someone’s favorite: true fans and consistency rituals
quotes.text: I find it so valuable to build that relationship with people. And it's even more valuable with podcasting because podcasting is such an intimate medium. You're in someone's ear and they're actively listening to you while they're going about their life.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Explains why podcasts can create unusually strong loyalty and connection compared to other content formats.

quotes.topic_title: Be someone’s favorite: true fans and consistency rituals
quotes.text: Someone once told me, "Make sure you're consistent with the time you release because you'll get people that are like, "It's Wednesday morning, where's my episode? This is how I... It's become a ritual in my life.""
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Actionable advice: consistent release timing helps turn your content into a habit/ritual for listeners.

quotes.topic_title: Be someone’s favorite: true fans and consistency rituals
quotes.text: And I actually surveyed the audience about 50 episodes in and ask, "Which was your favorite episode?" And every episode except one was someone's favorite.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: Concrete example showing that “favorite” is audience-specific—nearly any episode can deeply resonate with someone.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing a podcast topic and forcing a decision
quotes.text: What question someone said is, when you're at a dinner table, what's the thing that you talk about where you notice that everyone at the table is leaning in and trying to listen and pick your brain on and maybe sends you a text after?
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A practical litmus test for choosing a podcast topic based on real-world audience pull and organic curiosity.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing a podcast topic and forcing a decision
quotes.text: What do people reach out to you for expertise on? What do you spend your time going down deep rabbit holes on the internet on? Because all of those things are going to be part of your life as a creator.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A creator-market fit heuristic: align your show with what others already seek you out for and what you naturally research obsessively.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing a podcast topic and forcing a decision
quotes.text: So find some friend of yours that's like, "I'm tweeting about your podcast on Friday, or I'm going to include you in my newsletter next month." And give yourself an artificial deadline or even a real deadline to just put a stake in the ground.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A concrete method to break analysis paralysis by borrowing external accountability and time pressure.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing a podcast topic and forcing a decision
quotes.text: And you could change the name, you could pivot the topic, you could pivot the style of content. All those things can happen after, but just get started because you'll get to learn whether you like doing it, how it feels.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A counterweight to perfectionism: treat early decisions as reversible so you can start learning sooner.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing a podcast topic and forcing a decision
quotes.text: You could create a podcast and make a private feed and people can add a private feed to their podcast app. So if you want to get some feedback, you can just send people a URL and say, "Hey, paste this URL and the Apple Podcast player and listen to a couple episodes and let me know what you think." Before you make that plunge to send it to the whole world.
quotes.speaker: Chris Hutchins
quotes.context: A lightweight testing methodology for validating format and content with real listeners before a public launch.
